obvious_child

Obama always irritates me with his Judas kisses and promises to lower taxes. You know what? I'm still waiting for Bill's tax cut. It's not like you can wave a magic wand and make taxes go down.

 
 Any tax cut at this point by any candidate is nothing more then a loan. The last 7 years of Republican rule has resulted in so much red ink that our solvency as a country is in question. This tax cut alone was likely paid for entirely with borrowed money that will have to be paid back at some point with interest. That is by definition a loan. All tax cuts that are not meant with a decrease in spending are nothing more then mortgaging the future to pay for today. There is a clear reason why Reagan and Bush Jr. have presided over the two largest increases in debt in US history. 
 
 Neither candidate is the deficit hawk/fiscal conservative we need to get back into the black.
obvious_child

Don't change the subject, genius, McCain's not the one who says "no" to off-shore drilling yet is all for foreign oil dependency.

 
 Your ignorance of oil is astounding (and you wonder why no one takes you seriously here). Until the US becomes a price setter, which is technically impossible given how little we have, we will be dependent on foreign oil. XXXXXX across this country have some idiotic notion that pumping more here frees us from the commodity trading framework that spans the globe. That pumping oil off the coast of California will somehow mean cheaper oil here that is not priced based on a variety of factors, most of which we have no control over. Unless we can pump millions of barrels in the next few years daily, prices won't change at all. Last I checked, estimated production off the coast of Florida is only expected to be around 900,000 barrels a day. Saudi Arabia threw its 800,000 spare capacity at the world volume and priced did not move.
 
 Pickens is correct, We cannot drill ourselves out of this problem. 
 
 Frankly, I'd rather save that oil for more important things, such as fertilizer. We can eventually power our lives on alternative. Good luck trying to power our agriculture without oil based fertilizers. One of the most important, if not important discoveries on all Mankind was how to fix nitrogen. We frankly need our oil for food. Not transportation.
Jo Bennett

I started off on Obama, Jo replied on McCain, so you guess.

 
 The only reason you attack Obama is to make McCain seem better by comparison. I was simply pointing out how obviously partisan and/or ignorant your attack was. Posting something that rebuts the purpose of your argument is not changing the subject. Switching to a different topic entirely, particularly when you seem to have even less knowledge of the second topic than you do of the former, IS changing the subject.
Symbiote

tax cuts are the best way to restore people's eroding standard of living and boost the economy - but only if they are financed by spending cuts that are much larger.
 
 They're a secondary issue at this point in time and a distraction over the real issue which is spending - an issue on which neither candidate is any good at all.
 
 Oh and before the socialist ideologues cut me down - clearly the biggest candidates for spending cuts are
 
 1) the military, by a long shot
 
 &
 
 2) the failed drug war
 
 3) corporate bailouts and handouts
 
 Any candidate that doesn't commit to a radical reduction in spending is a joke, whether republocrat or demican
isly ilwott

We should be reminded that "tax cut" is the improper term here. It's "tax rate cuts" that can and generally do increase the tax revenue by stimulating the economy.
 
 The reduction in spending should be accomplished whether we lower the tax rates or not. The chances of that happening are slim as both sides of the aisle continue to grow the government and put more people on the public dole...and the word is "dole", not payroll as many government employees do not actually work.
Jo Bennett

The reduction in spending should be accomplished whether we lower the tax rates or not. The chances of that happening are slim as both sides of the aisle continue to grow the government and put more people on the public dole...and the word is "dole", not payroll as many government employees do not actually work.

 
 Evidence?
 
 Rather than tax cuts, which are a rather blunt instrument, the US government, and the UK government for that matter, should be using money saved from weapons and bailing out mortgage companies to build public infrastructure. Light rail networks linking the suburbs to city centres will reduce dependence on cars in the long term and in the short term provide a massive shot in the arm to manufacturing and construction. Couple this with funding R&D of new energy sources and you link economic recovery in the classic, effective Keynesian model with energy independence and tackling climate change.
isly ilwott

Evidence?
 
 Rather than tax cuts, which are a rather blunt instrument, the US government, and the UK government for that matter, should be using money saved from weapons and bailing out mortgage companies to build public infrastructure. Light rail networks linking the suburbs to city centres will reduce dependence on cars in the long term and in the short term provide a massive shot in the arm to manufacturing and construction. Couple this with funding R&D of new energy sources and you link economic recovery in the classic, effective Keynesian model with energy independence and tackling climate change.
Evidence of what? That neither side is hellbent to reduce spending? That many government "employees" do not actually work? You can take one look at our congressmen's records and see that some of them do no work. You can watch five men on a government maintenance crew standing around watching two men work and conclude that their paycheck is a dole. There are more people on the government payrolls at the national, state and local levels than are required to do the work. That means that some of them at any one time are on the dole. What more evidence do you need rather than to look around you? Government is the most inefficient method we have of accomplishing some worthy goals...and some of the goals that governments attempt to accomplish are not worth the money spent doing it. Our governement entities are often worse than labor unions replete with featherbedding free-loaders, employed by some friend that got elected to a job that has hiring powers attached. There are many people in government positions simply for the money only. They don't really have to produce...so they don't. It's these people I would cut from the dole.
 
 I noticed you did not quote my first two sentences. Does that mean you need no evidence of that point?
Jo Bennett

No, it just means I'm not going to waste time explaining the laffer curve to the ignorant. Again.
 
 I was asking for evidence that public employees do no work. By evidence I mean some form of measurable statistic or investigative report. Not the internet equivalent of "what some bloke down the pub told me".
isly ilwott

No, it just means I'm not going to waste time explaining the laffer curve to the ignorant. Again.
 
 I was asking for evidence that public employees do no work. By evidence I mean some form of measurable statistic or investigative report. Not the internet equivalent of "what some bloke down the pub told me".

 I doubt you'll find any statistics on how many employees actually work for a living, even when considering the private sector. In governement empoyment, it's extremely difficult to fire people. To assume that all who have jobs actually work is to be blind to reality.
 
 ..and you have no cause to assume that I visit pubs where blokes hang out.

obvious_child

We should be reminded that "tax cut" is the improper term here. It's "tax rate cuts" that can and generally do increase the tax revenue by stimulating the economy.

 
 From a base of Zero yes, they do increase tax revenue. What you failed to mention is that revenue from tax cuts is less then what would have already been collected in their absence. If tax cuts actually do increase revenue more then what normally would have been collected, they would pay for themselves. Good luck find any sane economist who agrees with that. So while tax cuts DO increase revenue from a baseline of Zero, they result in less revenue then what would have been collected without the tax cut.
